pageTitle: CIBC Poll: 60% of Canadians plan to contribute to their retirement this year, but many won't follow through | SYS-CON INDIA
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {23226=TORONTO, Feb. 11, 2013 /CNW/ - A new CIBC (CM:TSX) (CM: NYSE) poll reveals 60 per cent of eligible Canadians say they will invest in their retirement this year; however research from previous years finds many Canadians will not follow through., 34047=Results are based on a CIBC poll conducted by Harris/Decima, via teleVox, which surveyed 1740 Canadians between ages 18 and 72 (the age at which RRSPs must be converted to a Registered Retirement Income Fund).  The associated margin of error is +/-2.35%, 19 times out of 20. Polling was conducted between December 13, 2012 to January 7, 2013., 28047=Percentage breakdown of how Canadians plan to contribute to their retirement savings in 2013, by region:, 30185=Percentage of Canadians who plan to contribute to either an RRSP, TFSA, or both in 2013 compared to last year, by age:, 26389=Percentage of Canadians who intend to contribute to either an RRSP, TFSA, or both in 2013 compared to last year, by region:, 31862=Percentage breakdown of how Canadians plan to contribute to their retirement savings in 2013, by age:}
textBeforeTable: Percentage of Canadians who intend to contribute to either an RRSP, TFSA, or both in 2013 compared to last year, by region: Additional Poll Findings: Manage and Track Day-to-Day Spending Contribute Regularly Meet with an Advisor and Review your Savings Goals and Plan CIBC offers the following tips for Canadians to maximize Retirement Savings: Making smaller, regular contributions throughout the year is much easier than making one large lump-sum contribution to your RRSP," said Mr. Golombek.  "If you set up your regular savings plan so that a portion of each pay cheque automatically goes to an RRSP account or your TFSA then you can't spend it." Once Canadians have identified some extra savings they can contribute to their retirement, an easier way to follow through with your good intentions is to set up a regular investment plan. "By restructuring your debt, or reviewing monthly cash-flow, an advisor can help you find extra money to contribute towards your retirement savings," said Mr. Golombek. Mr. Golombek advises that while debt repayment is important, you shouldn't ignore your long term savings goal either. Budgeting Key to Making Retirement Savings Contributions "While it's positive that so many eligible Canadians plan to contribute towards their retirement this year, we know from previous years that only 26 per cent of eligible tax filers actually made a contribution to their RRSP
